cell.p: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.

This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.

Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.

Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Belgrads, Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
Steamers leave Suez every Thursday at 5p.m. for JEDDAH, salling as required as TOR (for Mount Sinel) and YAMBO, and sentualizing in alternate weeks so SUAKIM, MASSOWAH, HODRIDAH, and ADEN.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: Under the same mangaement. Beautifully situated on river. Accomodates 80 guests. Moderate terms. Entirely rebuilt since the fire, and fitted throughout in the most modern style. Beautiful Terrace overlooking river. Electric light throughout.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Flat calm, smooth sea, and clear weather throughout the whole of yesterday, the temperature being slightly warm. At 1 a.m. the barometer fell a little and the wind sprang up lightly from the South. It is now considerably cooler and fresh. Barometer falling.

THURSDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1904.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR.
div.p: The latest London newspapers to hand contain most interesting accounts of the terribly dramatic finale of the Port Arthur Fleet. One by one the Russian Navy in the Far East has been knocked out of action by the methodical Japanese. Taking as few risks as possible with their own precious and none too numerous battleships and cruisers, Togo, Kamimura and Uriu have slowly but thoroughly wrested from Russia any pretension to sea-power. One by one, as occasion offered, after that first magnificent dash by the destroyer flotilla I which found the Russians making merry or asleep while their country's honor depended on watchful efficiency, the Russian ships have been accounted for. The Varyag' and "Koreitz" were extinguished together at Chemulpo. The “Rurik” was hainmered out of existence in the Vladivostok cruisers' action with Kamimura Cunctator, the plucky little "Novik” was driven ashore soon afterwards, the “Petropavlovsk” was destroyed by a mine, no doubt by & designed and Japanese chain-mine, and the disastrous sortie of August accounted for more being put out of action, with the result that when the more disastrous return was made to the precarious shelter of Port Arthur harbour, only the battleships "Poltava,” “Peresviet," "Pobieda," "Sevastopol," and "Retvisan,” with the cruiser "Bayan," remained out of the fine fleet commanded by Admiral Stark when the war broke

div.head: Sunlight
div.p: Clothes will last longer if SUNLIGHT SOAP is used.
Makes Linen Whiter and Coloured things Brighter.
FULL DIRECTIONS ON WRAPPER.
Soap

out. Since the Japanese assaulted with success 203 Metre Hill, obviously the key to the Russian defence, more disasters have followed. The “Poltava" has been sunk where she lay at anchor, the "Retvisan" is on her beam ends, it is reported that the | "Peresviet" has gone down, the “Bayan” has run aground, while the "Pobieda” and | “Pallada" have received a fearful and shattering fire from the captured eminence which dominates the harbour. All is thus plainly finished for the Port Arthur remnant. At Vladivostok the naval situation is quite as desperate. The "Gromoboi" and "Bogatry" are not fit to put to sea, even if neither of them has gone to pieces, and the “Rossia” is in no better case. The Japanese squadrons, | in fact, refitted and repainted and probably | little the worse for all the fighting, can now | turn their undivided attention to the Baltio Armada when, or if, it comes. Only destruction Trån lia before it. To prodaonta the forlorn hope seems the veriest madness, and unless the ill-manned, ill-disciplined, and hetero. geneous squadrons are recalled at once, it may be too late to save them from the fate that has overtaken their fellows and predecessors,

This destruction of the Port Arthur Fleet, Tas it lay at anchor within the shell-stricken harbour, has all the drama of tragedy. One must inevitably suppose that they have been thus ignobly and pitiably destroyed because they were already, before tho Japanese had secured their position on 203 Metre Hill, incapable of steaming or fighting. Had a single" ship been able to get out of the deadly harbour and run for death or glory firing even half her guns it is inconceivable that the desperate attempt should not have been made. It then becomes practically certain that the ships have been helplessly and hopelessly shattered for some time. At the same time this does not explain, nor is it possible to understand, the absence of any previous attempt to break out by the Port Arthur Fleet. After the disastrous sortie, ill-managed and not pushed to its logical conclusion, these ships were certainly capablo of some sort of fight. Obviously the loss of one Japanese battleship would have been worth their destruction, and why they made no at tempt to do some serious damage to their enemy before their careers as Russian iron clads were finished is something difficult to understand. It looks like a continuation of that incompetence and indecision which has reduced Russia to an insignificant position amongst the Naval Powers of the world, and has even, as military critics in Russia are candidly writing, lost her the war. Possibly the Port Arthur ships were waiting for the magical Armada, which was blundering abont in the North Sea and creeping out at a snail's pace while every minute was worth its weight in gold. There would have been something stirring and melodramatic in that final and torlorn sortie which we have been expecting any time these last three months. The deepest tragedy surrounds this desperate end without a blow struck in self-defence.

For ourselves there is a moral to be drawn from what has happened at Port Arthur. The prime importance of séa-power has never, since the day of Trafalgar, been so clearly demon: strated. We have only to turn to the frank pessimism of Russian military critics to learn how much has depended, does and will depend, on the command of the sea. It is already recognised that Russia cannot bring the war to a successful conclusion unless the arrival of the Baltic Fleet changes the whole aspect of the naval situation. Failing that miracle it is beginning to be said that the war must come to a swift and ignominious end, and that it is & miracle rather to be prayed for, as Port Arthur once was prayed for, than reasonably expected, is as clearly recognised. Japan has won, 80 far, because her ships were ready and efficient. Our ships are ready and efficient, too, and we need have, perhaps, no fear on that score, though the vitalimportance of an overwhelming ly powerful Navy for us is the one thing we can never afford to lose sight of,

div.head:
PORT ARTHUR.
JAPANESE WARSHIP SUNK
A TALE OF HORROR.
div.p: The Daily Telegraph learns from Chifu that a messenger from Dalny states that another Japanese warship, larger than the Saiyen, was also šunk on the 30th ult. off Port Arthur by a torpedo-boat.
The Japanese cruisers sank two Russian torpedo-boats of Port Arthur on the 25th ult.

Reuter's correspondent before Port Arthur says that the effect of the dynamite grenades was appalling in the recent fighting. The dead were so torn to pieces that they were merely an unrecognisable mass of flesh, bones and fragments. The hundreds of killed unearthed from the unfilled trenches presented an awful spectacle of horror. Heavy timber and steel plates from the bomb-proofs were shattered into splinters. (Reuter.)

div.head:
THE BALTIC FLEET.
DEPARTURE FROM DJIBOUTI.
div.p: Admiral Foelkersahm's Squadron has left. (Havas.)

div.head:
RUSSIAN OUTSPOKENNESS.
CAPT. KLADO A POPULAR HERO.
div.p: Captain Klado's outspokenness in criticising the inaction of the Admiralty regarding the reinforcement of the Baltic Fleet, and his consequent punishment, have excited in an extraordinary degree public sympathy. He is being made a popular hero by all classes here. (Reuter.)

div.head: A TOLSTOI'S BRAVERY.
div.p: André Tolstoi, an 'ordnance officer, son of the great author, has received the St. George's Cross for his bravery. (Havas.)

div.head:
RUSSIAN REFORMS.
MOSCOW'S ACTION.
div.p: The Town Council yesterday resolved unanimously that the following reforms are absolutely necessary for the protection of the subject against official caprice:-the abolition of exceptional laws, the freedom of conscience, press, and meeting, and popular representation in the Government. (Reuter.)

div.head:
FRANCE AND SIAM.
FRENCH APPOINTMENTS.
div.p: In consequence of the Franco-Siamese Convention, Siam has appointed M. Padoux, of the French Consular Service, to be a legal adviser to the Government, and Colonel Goullet to the command of the native militia in the Provinces of Patabang avd Siemreap. (Reuter.)

div.head:
ITALO-AMERICAN ARBITRATION.
TREATY SIGNED.
div.p: The Italo-American arbitration treaty has been signed here to-day. It is identical with the others signed by the United States. (R.)

div.head: THE HUNGARIAN DIET.
div.p: The Diet assembled quietly to-day, the guard to which the Opposition had objected being absent. (Reuter.)

div.head: SPANISH CABINET CRISIS.
div.p: The Cabinet has resigned. (Havas.)

div.head:
GENERAL ELECTION.
LORD HAMILTON NOT TO STAND.
div.p: Lord Hamilton's Conservative opponent having declared against Protection while supporting Mr. Balfour, bis Lordship will not stand at the next General Election. (Reuter.)

div.head: M. DE PLEHVE'S ASSASSIN.
div.p: Sasonoff, the assassin of M. de Plehve, has been sentenced to hard labour for life. (H.)

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: One new locality was declared infected with cattle plague to-day.

div.head: THE STANDARD LIFE ASSURANCE COMPANY.
div.p: Mr. E. A. Harrison, general manager of Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son (Egypt), Ltd., has joined the local board of this company.

div.head: NEW DOCTORS
div.p: Messrs. Pilpoul Pinhas and N. de Gélat, doctors, and Karl Summermacher, chemist, have been authorised to exercise their profession in Egypt.

div.head: AN IMPORTANT SALE
div.p: of harness, vehicles and tentage, belonging to the Army of Occupation, will be held to-morrow at 9 a.m. at Mustapha Barracks.

div.head: MISTLETOE AND HOLLY
div.p: are to be given free to the customers of Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd., Old Bourse Palace, Alexandria. Early application for same is requested.

div.head: REUNION DES FAMILLES SOCIETY.
div.p: The society's first ball of the season will be given in Monferrato's Hall on Saturday, January 7 next, another being given on the 28th of that month.

div.head: ASSAULT-AT-ARMS.
div.p: On Friday next at 9.30 p.m. M.M. Fiandro & Maillet, professors of fencing at the Egyptian Fencing Club will give an assault-at-arms at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo.

div.head: IRRIGATION TRUST CERTIFICATES.
div.p: The Bank of England announces the numbers of 253 Four per Cent. Egyptian Government Irrigation Trust Certificates which have been drawn for redemption on January 1, 1905.

div.head: SALE OF WORK.
div.p: The sale in connection with the Y.W.C.A., Cairo, to-morrow will be opened by the Countess of Cromer at 3.30 p.m. The entrance fee will be P.T. 5 and there will be a ventriloquial entertainment at 4.30.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: 11 vessels passed through the Canal on 12th inst., 6 of which were British, 3 German, 2 Austrian. The receipts for the day were frs. 250,037.87. From the 1st to 12th December they amounted to frs. 4,335,046.77.

div.head: PICKPOCKET.
div.p: An American lady was adroitly relieved of her handbag, containing a large sum of money, while purchasing a ticket at the Alexandria railway station. The thief decamped and has not been seen since.

div.head: SLAVE TRADE REPRESSION.
div.p: The Slave Trade Repression Department manumitted during November a total of 19 slaves; 5 Sudanese women at Cairo, 2 Abyssinians and 2 Abyssinian women at Suez, 3 Sudanese women and 2 men on the Red Sea littoral, and a Sudanese woman at Assouan.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL GEOGRAPHICAL SOCIETY.
div.p: The next meeting of the K. G. S. will be held in the hall of the Mixed Courts, Cairo, on Saturday next at 3.30 p.m., when M. Fourtau will lecture on "La Cataracte d'Assouan et la Theorie des Tourbillous," and Bonola Bey will give some "African Notes."

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE.
div.p: The variety company at this theatre continues to draw large and appreciative audiences. To-morrow evening, a new ballet, entitled "A Marriage in Seville," will be given. The first masked ball of the season will be given on Saturday, after the performance.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE.
div.p: The Soarez Italian operetta company will make its debut at this theatre on the 20th inst. with the ever-popular La Poupée. The company have a very strong caste, including Signa. Amelia Soarez herself, and their repertoire comprises all the best and must popular of light operas.

div.head: SALT MONOPOLY.
div.p: The salt sales of the Salt and Soda Company during November aniounted to L.E.23,126, as against L.E.21,397 during the same month last year. The total sales from the 1st January amounted to L.E.229,816, as compared with L.E.229,903 in the corresponding period of last year.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: The London Stock Exchange Committee have received an application to allow the following security to be quoted in the Official List: Agricultural Bank of Egypt; further issue of £625,000 31 per Cent. Bunds, 1924-49, Nos. 29,301 to 32,425 of £100 each, and 35,551 to 51,175 of £20 each.

div.head: CONCERT SAKELARIDIS.
div.p: A concert will be given on Friday next, 16th inst., in the Khedivial Hotel, by the Sakelaridis family, who charned lovers of music in Munich and Athens last year. The Alexandrian public, for the | first time, will have the opportunity of hearing popular Greek songs which are considered by the highest musical authorities of Europe as the pure inheritance of ancient Greek music.

div.head: COTTON SPINNING PROFITS.
div.p: Mr. William Tattersall, of Manchester, in his private circular on Friday last, says that the profitable state of spinning will hardly show itself this year. The profit for the past twelve months, Lending November 30, for about eighty-seven concerns, is only £30,000. Last year for ninety mills the loss was about $44,000. The capital employed in these mills is upwards of £3,000,000.

div.head: IS IT MURDER!
div.p: The dead body of a native man was found by the Alexandria city police yesterday evening near the Mahmoudieh Canal. It was conveyed to the Government Hospital, where the medical examination showed that la rib had been broken from the blow of a nabout. The brothers of the divorced wife of the deceased were arrested on suspicion of being the murderers, as they swore to kill him on account of their sister, his late wife,

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Montazah Mosque has been decorated in honour of the anniversary of the birthday of the elder son of his Highness the Khedive, who enters on his eighth year to-morrow. His Highness will attend Friday prayers at that mosque. In the evening & large number of Uleina and Egyptian notables and officials will be invited at Montazah, where prayers will be given and the Korau read.

In honour of the birthday of the Prince, the | Mosque of Abul Abbas Mursy at Alexandria has been decorated, and this evening at 8 p.m. prayers will be given which will be followed | by reading from the Koran-el-Cheief.
The Khedive will probably return to Cairo from Montazh on Saturday afternoon.
His Highness will preside at the Council of Ministers which is expected to meet on Monday.

div.head:
ARCHDUKE OTHOX.
COMING TO EGYPT.
div.p: The Archduke Othon has left for Egypt.(H.)

div.head: THE RAILWAY COMMISSION.
div.p: Lord Farrer, president of the Railway Commission, and Mr. Bury left Alexandria yesterday for Europe by the North German Lloyd's S.S. Schleswig.

Major Le Breton, R.E., third member of the Commission, will stay in Egypt for a few weeks | longer, in order to complete his report on the reorganisation of the general financial administration of the Egyptian Government Railways. The report will be made public shortly.

div.head: PHARMACY REGULATIONS.
div.p: The reply of the Director-General of the Sanitary Department to the committee of the l. Cairo pharmacists re the Sanitary Regulations has been received, and was read at last night's committee ineeting.

div.head: FINANCIAL ADVISER'S NOTE.
div.p: The Financial Adviser's Note on the Budget will be published on the 24th inst. We understand that it will be of far greater | length, and will go more into detail, than | any previous publication.

div.head: CASE OF PLAGUE AT SUEZ.
div.p: Suez, Wednesday.--Yesterday afternoon a wative girl was fouud in the Arab quarter at Suez to be suffering from bubonic plugue, and was at once conveyed to the Government | Hospital for treatment.
Owing to this case, Suez is now doclared 1 infected, and several steamers are passing through the canal in voluntary quarantine, without communicating with the port.

div.head: NILE VALLEY CO.
div.p: According to the latest news from the Nile | Valley, dated the 7th inst., we are informed that the sample mill during the month of November crushed 37 tons of ore, from which 75oz. of gold were obtained. A letter dated Noveinber 19 states that the mill was running for the month of November on the fines - from No. 1 winze, and the stone broken from the North and South Drives of the 150ft. level.

div.head: ANGLO-AFRICAN WHO'S WHO.
div.p: This is the first edition of the “AngloAfrican Who's Who." As it embraces an entire continent, there are of necessity some Jeficiencies. It is interesting to dwellers in Egypt, as the lists which the editor sent out have been filled in by many people here who, for some inscrutable reason, are not included in "Who's Who." For example, Johnson Pasha gives a column of interesting autobiogra. phical detail. Judge Marshall, Brewster Bey, Chakour Pasha, Mr. Rowlatt, Socrates Spiros Bey, Mr. George Royle, Mr. Trevithick, Mr. Bonham-Carter, who are all omitted from "Who's Who,'' have been given ample space for histories of their lives and achievements, so it is obvious that this useful work should find many readers in Egypt. The bulk of the work naturally deals with South Africans and the information given is very full.

div.head: THE ARAB'S OLD CREED.
div.p: Mr. Ditlef Kielsen has published an interesting monograph entitled "Die altarabische Mondreligion und die Mosaische Ueberlieferung." The first part, on the worship of the moon by the ancient Arabs, is full of notes. The author considers that the word sabat (sabbat of the cuneiform inscriptions) is of foreign origin. In the Babylonian language the word should be schabtu, from waschab, to settle, to repose. The word sabat is a direct reproduction of the Arabic thabat, from wathaba, to settle, the Arabic th not being represented in Babylonian except by the letter s., The second part of the Mosaic translation is employed in settling the origin of the Jewish religion from the Arab lunar worship. (Strasburg; Trübner.)

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. Anatolia sailed from Malta on Tuesday evening, and is due here, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, on Saturday morning.
The Moss liner Philæ sailed hence this! morning for Liverpool with general cargo, including 4,992 bales cotton.
The Moss liner Rameses sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due here on Sunday morning next, with passengers, mails, and general Cargo

div.head: EXPEDITION FROM CAIRO.
TO STUDY AFRICAN RAILWAYS.
div.p: An expedition will shortly start from Cairo under the leadership of M. Salesses, | the manager of the railways in French Guinea, who has been commissioned by the Colonial authorities to study all the railway systems in Africa except those of Algeria, and those which would take him too far afield, such as the Djibouti line. His duty will be to examine at first-hand all the systems of other Powers in Africa, in order that he may profit | by anything which he may think worthy of imitation by the French colonial railways. M. Salesses will start from Cairo and go to Khartoum by rail. From Khartoum he will go to Gondokoro and Uganda, travelling from Port| Florence to Mombasa by rail. After studying the German East African line he will go from Beira to Fort Salisbury and Buluwayo, and having visited the Victoria Falls will reach the Cape vid Kimberley. The German, Portuguese, Congo Free State, and English lines on the West Coast of Africa are also to be investi. I gated by him, and finally the lines in the French colonies, including those from Dakar to Saint Louis, and from Kayes to the Niger will also be exainined. At the conclusion of his I journey M. Salesses will make an exhaustive report, similar to that which M. Julledière made on the railways of India for the authorities in Indo-China. This mission, whioh is well worth attention in England and the Colonies, is significant of the thoroughness with which the French have of late years taken up Colonial questions. Nothing is now left to chance, but everything is carefully studied, and the advances which have been made in West Africa and Madagascar show that the French are determined to do away with the reproach of pot being a colonising nation. A little more enterprise among private citizens is all they need to make their Colonial possessions successful from every point of view.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET
div.p: The weather and the vagaries of the Yankee manipulators have had more to do with the depression of the Stock Markets during the last few days than matters political. The former has | for days past been of the "vile" order—wet and depressing. The latter are progressing steadily and surely to the end already foreshadowed in my former articles. The recent doings at Port Arthur are all against the war party in St. Petersburg ; consequently those who are workJing for peace, are more hopeful that theirlabours will bear fruit. I understand the efforts of our neighbours across the Channel have made distinct headway in the right direction during the last few days.

Egyptian Stocks have given way somewhat since our last from the above causes, although they continue to steer a course of their own. The Cotton Market situation has had an adverse effect on prices in this market, more especially on the Bank shares, Nationals having dropped to 23 and Agriculturals to 10 id. Land shares keep steady, Daira Sugar keep very firm at 5%, and there has undoubtedly been influential support on this side, as Paris was a fairly large seller warly in the week, but this had little effect on the market. Apart from the rise in sugar, these shares have an intrinsic value of their own and are worth watching. Salt and Soda hold their price well at 2 and might easily have another upward run. The late general manager, with his block of deferred shares, however, should have something to say regarding the proposed amalgamation.

In general markets the main points of interest have been the Japanese successes at Port Arthur, which were however pretty fully discounted, and the sharp break yesterday in the American Market on the fall in Amalga mated Copper. Americans were very wild for some time, but the recovery was even more rapid than the fall, as London took most of the cheap Stock. Kaffies are neglected, but there is not really much set-back in prices, and the | undertone is good. Egyptian Mining shares have been weak during the last few days, Nile Valleys having falleu to 2), and United Afrisans to 11. At this level they should be worth attention as there is a general and confident feeling that we shall see renewed activity in the mining section. The company we mentioned a fortnight ago — The Corporation of Western Egypt - is, we hear, being steadily applied for and likely to go well. The names of the | Cairo board should certainly inspire confidence.
There is little to say of general business which has been on a small scale, as is generally the case at the end of the year, but opinion that the New Year will bring a further revival seems general.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: ALL persons having claime against the estate of the late Yousbasbi 0. F. ARM-1 STRONG, Coast Guard Administration, will | submit the same to Major R. PRINGLE on or before the 14th January, 1905, after | which date no claims will be received.
All persons indebted to the late C. F. ABMSTRONG will communicate with :
MAJOR R. PRINGLE,
President, Committee of Adjustment,
Arsenal, Alexandria.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: SALE at Mustaphs Pasha Barracks, at 9 a.m. 16th inst. of Vehicles, Harness, Saddlery, Tentage, Camp equipment, etc. 25035-1.

div.head: RAMADAN IN HYDE PARK.
div.p: A REMARKABLE AND IMPRESSIVE SERVICE.
A London correspondent, writing unter date of Friday last, remarks:

There could be no greater contrast in the ethics associated with Marble Arcb, Hyde Park, than the simple devotions of a little band of Mahomedans which assernbled this morning to offer : “Prayers to Allah and Ma.. homed his Prophet," and the nondescript and often impious meetings which take place there every Sunday afternoon. There was no muezzin to call the faithful to their devotions, but the rain and the cold did not appear to affect the attendance or damp the religious fervour of the devotees.

This was the first day of Beyram, and the celebration was arranged by the PanIslamic Society. Between thirty and forty Moslems, some wearing turbans and armed with mats of linoleum, which were spread on the wet ground, assembled at eleven o'clock. The celebration was of a remarkable and most impressive character. When the chief priest, robed, in Mahomedan canonicals, commenced the prayer to Allah, the worshippers fell on their knees in two rows, with their faces towards the East. At the close of the prayer the people bowed low and kissed the ground twice. After a hymn a second prayer was devoutly offered up, and again the devotees kissed the ground twice, and when they rose from their knees they embraced each other in Moslem fashion, and the celebration was at an end.
The Mahomedan community in London have no mosque, but plans have been prepared for the erection of one of architectural magnificence, with a dome 200 feet high.

div.head: OBITUARY.
MR. WALTER HICKS.
div.p: There appears to be some fatality about the managership of the Imperial Ottoman Bank at Cairo, for the death of Mr. Moxley was soon followed by that of Mr. Wood, and now we regret to announce the death of Mr. Walter Hicks, manager of the Imperial Ottoman Bank at Cairo, who expired at 11.15 o'clock last night from cerebral hæmorrhage. Mr. Hicks was born in 1855, and entered the service of the bank at the age of 16. He had successively been controller at the bank's Port Said agency, chief accountant at Alexandria, and sub-manager and manager at Cairo. He was appointed manager at Cairo in May this year, in succession to Mr. Wood.

Mr.Hicks went for a drive yesterday afternoon, when he was seized with an apoplectic attack.He was taken home and appeared to be going on as well as could be expected when death ensued from the above-mentioned cause. His funeral takes place this afternoon at 2.30, from the Imperial Ottoman Bank.
Mr. Hicks leaves a widow and two daughters, one aged about 12 and the other about 6, to whom we tender our deep sympathy.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit – within certain necessary limits - free discussion.

div.head: THE LATE YOUSBASHI ARMSTRONG.
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,—As there appears to be no doubt as to the fact that the late Yousbashi Armstrong caught confluent small-pox while convalescent in hospital, I think that in justice to that excellent institution, the German Deaconesses' Hospital at Alexandria, the authorities of the hospital ought to hold an enquiry into the matter. As there does not exist in Egypt any hospital reserved for infectious cases, the, unfortunate death of this young Englishman will cause considerable apprehension to all those who in future have to go into hospital. For the sake of the public, and in the interests of the hospital, a careful investigation should be made into the circumstances attending this is tragical affair. Surely it is high time for the Egyptian Government to build a small-pox hospital. Small-pox is prevalent in Egypt : last year 2,118 cases occurred, If it is so infectious It! that a patient in a hospital, recovering from an illness, can contract the disease without contact, but merely through the medium of the air, then nobody in a hospital is safe if there is a small-pox case under treatment at the same time.
Yours truly,

div.head:
PORT ARTHUR.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: This is from one in agony to think what may happen to the glorious and brave General Stoessel and the brave garrison. Surely these heroes have now sufficiently upheld the honour of their “Little Father,” the Tsar, without being condemned to die at their posts.--Can nothing be done to avoid this? Europe awake! and think. The Japs are willing to give honorable terms.
Geo. B. ALDERSON.
Norland House, Bulkeley, Ramleh.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL.
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the see Central position. Under English management 81.11.904

A very successful dance was given last night at the British Agency. Over 400 invitations had been issued, and dancing was prolonged to a late hour. Among those present we noticed Lady Beatrice Thynne, Mme and Mlles. de Villebois, Marchesa Salvago-Raggi, M. Lecomte, Don Ricardo Larios, Mr. and Mrs. A. D. Alban, Hon. F. G. Morgan. Hon, C. Davey, and Mrs. Davey, Hon. F. Lindley and Mrs. Lindley, Mr. Carton de Wiart, Mr. and Mrs. Sciortino, Mr. Carter Wilson, Coles Pasha, Mrs. Coles and her two daughters, Sir W. Garstin, ·- Sir John Rogers, Mr. and Miss Rees, Colonel and ; Mrs. Asser, Mr. and Mrs. Cotterill, Dr. Keatinge, Wilhem Shakoor Bey and Miss Shakoor, Mr. and Mrs. Brunyate, Judge and Mrs. Willmore, Mr. and Mrs. Rowlatt, Miss Caillard, officers of the Army of Occupationand the E. A., the Agency staff, etc.
Lord and Lady Newport, who were married last July, have just gone back to England from a trip up the Nile. They will take a town house of their own next year.
Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alex. andria, returned from Cairo yesterday evening.

The future prospects of Chitty Bey are attracting the attention of the vernacular Press. One newspaper yesterday announced that he would succeed Harari Pasha, while another native journal states that he will not be transferred to the Finance Ministry. .
Michalla Pasha's resignation of the post of Sub-Director-Genoral ot Customs has been accepted, as from January 1, 1905.

We regret to hear of a rather serious accident which happened to Mrs. Charles Barber and her four-year old child the night be fore last. Mrs. Barber was driving down Nébi. Daniel-street when her carriage was run into by another one. The shaft. of the latter entered Mrs. Barber's carriage and she,, as well as her child, sustained somewhat severe injuries.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Aujourd'hui à midi et demi)
div.p: Malgré la hausse de ce matin tout fait prévoir qu'il n'y aura pas de reprise sérieuse avant la fin janvier ou le commencement de février.

Les motifs, en effet, qui ont détermine la débacle actuelle, ne sont pas de ceux que disparaissent en un jour. Il faudra à notre marché un mois ou deux au moins pour se relever. Les gros spéculateurs ayant suli des pertes énormes en coton ont du vendre leurs paquets de titres. L'affluence des vendeurs à la corbeille a malheureusement coincidé avec la liquidation de fin de mois et avec l'approche des fêtes du premier du l'an. Une baisse s'en est suivie qui a jeté la panique parmi la foulu des petits spéculateurs. Si l'on jouie qu'à cette époque de l'année les affaires sont mortes, que le négociants arrêtent leurs comptes et réalisent pour liquidcr avant de commencer les comptes de l'exercice suivant, on comprend jusqu'à un certain point le mauvaise humuer du marché et le baisse continu inévitable qui doit se produire lorsque tous le monde veut se défaire de titres que personne ne se soucie d'acquérir. Aussi le peut-on se dissimuler que la défiance a gagné les plus opimistes à tel point que les valeurs les plus solides elles-mêmes sont dépréciées.
Cette tendance subite et générale à réaliser a rendu la liquidation de fin du mois très laborieuse et n'a pu qu'aggraver la situation déja existante.
Il est juste d'ajouter qu'un certain nombre de qétenteurs s'efforcent d'ebrayer la baisse et qu'ils y réussissent en partie.
Les marchés européens suivent pour les Yalegre égy puennes le mouvement local e Acousent eux aussi une baisse sensible.

Disons encore que la hausse de la fin du mois dernier avait été quelque peu exugérée, que la spéculation entrainée par un courant de hausse irrésistible a'y était un peu trop abandonnée. La baisse de Now. York a été le coup de foudre qui a ramene les exaltés à une plus juste appréciation des ohoses.

Comme cette débiole est due à des motifs qui pour la piupart auront disparu en février prochain, que le cuton lui-mêmt, caus: initiale du tout le mal, uura proba blement regagné du terrain, on s'attend ge néralement pour outte date à une bonne reprise et à un redoublement d'activité.
Le msroué, après sa dégringoladu d'hiv. après-midi, &repris un peu ce matin sui toute la ligue.
La Banque Nationale a ouvert à 21 3/8; une demi-Leure après, tlle alttigiaitu 18/16; elle clôture a 21 7/8 vendeurs.
De même l'Agricole qui outait 9 5/01 vendeurs est remontéu ensuite à 9 7/8.

Et ainsi de tuite pour la plupart det valeurs mouvementées ; la Delta Lani rii prend à 37,16 venduurs, la Duïcs à 21 17 acheteurs, la Fılacart à 13/16 Vuodeuit, la Salt & boda à 37/6 acheteurs, los Banque d'Athènes à 123 1/4 vendeurs et les Privilégiés Tran Ways a 138 achettura.
D'autre part, la Urown brewery tuinb. à 206 nominal et la Brasourie uus Pyro mides à 108 venduara.
Les Cotton Mills fléchissent également 6/9, coure purement nominal.
En baitsy aussi l'Anglo-American Nin 1 à 4 1/4 et la Delta Ligbt à 14 1/4.
Le nombre des affairts & é.é relative ment considérable. La corbeille des cotun avait été comp.èrement désertée à un moment donné.
Cette reprise, provenant de ce que les spéculateurs au découvert ont racotté ou qu'ils avaient vendu cul jours derniera, de Bera probablement que m mentanée.

div.head: SAISIE D'ANTIQUITES.
div.p: Avant-hier à 8h. a.m , un at:roupement inusité a été remarqué à l'entrée du cara col de l'Ezbékieb. Les p1828ut-, employér de maisons de commerce ou fonctionnairer du gouvernement, curieux de savoir quel événement sensationn I retenait les oisifs aux abords du district de police, des. sendaient du tramway, se mélaient à la foule, jetaient ua rega det rejoignai ni en courant le véhicule. Les plus curieux interrogeaient et appreoaient que des charrettes qui contenaient ces momiei avaient été saisies I y avait aussi des ustensiles et d'autres objets antiques.

Le propriétaire, qui eurveillait le transpo-t, a été ar. êté par la polic. Il a déclaré ayoir xuberé ces pièces au Service disoni. quités et les avoir gardées pendant un cer tain temps à son domicile.
Le service des aniiquités & é:é avisé et une enquête est ouverto pour établir s'il y B bi n ucbat ou conirebunde.

En réali é il n'y ty it pas de momite volé g ou ach tés, mais de vieux fa cophg sans importaoce que le propriétuire B'é ait procuré à prix d'argent. Quant aux ustensiles, ils n'étaient qu'une imitation des aptique. L'enquête l'a bien démontré, et l'individu soupçonné de contrebande a ete remis en lib 1té.

div.head: Comites Municipaux
div.p: Cet après-midi, à 3 heures, le conseil l'estimation se réunira au Palais Munioipal pour trancher diverses questions concernant des excédents du tanzim. Cette réunion sera suivie d'une séance du Comité financier où sera discuté le projet du bud. get pour 1905, présenté par l'Administrateur de la Municipalité.

div.head: Alexandria Water Companpy.
DIVIDENDE INTERIMAIRE
div.p: Un dividende intérimaire de deux shellipge et six punce par action de 65 et de dix shellings par action de £ 20 est payeble le 15 courant, sur présentation des coupons de cette échéance à l'Anglo Egyptian Bank Ld, à Alexandria.

Afia de donner suite à la décision de l'Assemblée Généraly Extraordinaire du 27 Mars 1889, par laquelle chaque action de £ 20 fut convertie en 4 actions de £5, et à la demande du Stock Exchange de Londres, qui en donnant la cote anx actions de la Compagnie a exigé que toutes les actions de la Vie formeraient partie d'une segle série de Nos. de 1 à 100,000; il deviunt absolument nécessaire de présenter tous les titres de $20, afin d'y timbrer les nouveaux numéros et d'attacher aux titres une nouvelle feuille de coupons représenBentant quatre actions chacune portant aussi ces numéros.

Pour cette raison MM. les porteurs des titres de £20 sont priés de présenter à l'Anglo Egyptian Bank La. à Alexandrie, luurs titres du £ 20 en même temps que lt coupon du 15 courant, et la Banque lear donnera en échange un certificat de dépôt, contre le retour duquel les titres de £ 20 seront rendus aux propriétaires, monis des nouveaux numéros et coupons.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT.
div.p: The Market this week has been depressed, and only a small business has resulted ; quotstions being reduced i @lo for current qualities and to tor Fme and also Upper | Egypt.
A good business has been done in Egyptian Futures, the following being the latest values:Dec. 7.31 Feb. 7.0 Apl. 6..58 Jan. 7.10 Mar. 6.60 May 6.58.

American Futures. The Market this week has undergone a very serious experience, the Bureuu' estimate of the Crop, amouuting to 12,162,000 bales, produced a panic, enormous quantities of Cotton were thrown over, and prices tell 50 points on one day (Monday). Since then, there has been a slow re-adjustment of values, with, however, many weak moments; for instance on Tuesday, when prices tell 10 points, the current month wuching 1.06. Tu-day, with a steadier feeling, values are fully 10 points above the lowest rates, but still 57 @ 19 points below those of last Thursday. The position in one of great uitficulty; prices would appear to have tallen to a point of comparative safety considering the good trade conditions and the absolutely depleted supplies at the commencement of the season, but a Crop of 12 millions, probably more, promises a supply at least half a million in excess of the most liberal requirements, and it is just this unknown surplus that may check speculation and cause present prices, modu rate as they are, to be too high for the absorption of the superabundant supply.

div.head: Mahmoud Sami Pasha El Baroudi.
(Special Memoir).
div.p: If it were the duty of a newspaper to implicitly whey the maxim, De mortuis wil nisi wewn, the death of Mahmoud Sami Pasha e Baroudi, which we announced in Bunday's issue, should it without any uiment. But the sinister part which the late ha played in bringing about the crisis in hintory of modern Erypt, known locally as "Events," is part and parcel of the history this wountry, and we must perforce give eruunt of his deels. Mahmoud Pasha Summert bis surname of El Baroudi the Drewder maker to the fact that his father was Director of the Powder Vill. He had noching triking about his appearance, except an unpleasant quint, coupled with the habit of 1'er looking into one's face when speaking. no means partieularly gifted, or even distinguished as an administrator, he, nevertheless, milecee led in climbing to the top of the tree, thanks to a certain shrewdness and a remarkmidle titlent for intrigue. Utterly unprincipled and rely to do anything to gain his ends, he necessfully trailed on the weaknesses and hunders of his betters, and he had the reputasion of never having missed an opportunity of in gratiating his self with men at the helm. In turn the servile coprtier, first of Ismail, to whom he owed almost Everything and whom he professed to worship, and then of Tewfik, die was of course a fervent satellite of "herit, Riaz, and Nubar, according to the political barometer of the day. Always courtter the dispenser of favours, the man in power, it could be expected that he wonld join "the rulonels" as soon as Arabi was likely to become master of the situation. It mattered indeed little that he was a member of Cherif's cabinet, that he had pledged himself to stand and fall with bischief ; ---such tritling considerations had dy weight, and now we know that Baroudi was the soul of the military conspiracy against his colleagues. But we must not anticipate events.

Educated at Constantinople at Ismail's ex. piense, he gained his "spurs" at the Grand Vizierate, where he remained for seven years is a clerk, and on his return to Egypt he lingered for some years in subordinate positions until bis marriage with a daughter of Ismail's fala, or neroe, obtained him, in addition to a handsome dower, the position of aide-de camp to his Higbness.

Thus launched into the official world he complacently sunned himself in his generous master's favor, until a domestic mishap threw a cloud over his fortunes, and deprived him for a time of the golden advantages of what he or worsed to call the vitiated atmosphere of courts. It appears that he discovered one slay a tender weakness of his better half for a young and enterprising musician ; and not satisfied with killing the disturber of matrimonial harmony, be likewise murdered the taother of his wife's lover and her slave. As to his wife and mother-in-law, they had to start for a trip up the White Nile, "whence no one returns." Ismail Pasha frowner, he was fond of his dach, but Mahmoud Sami manged to get his cause so ably pleaded that he was soon allowed to return to Cairo, and passing a sponge over this little episode his Highness pardoned the ferorious Othello. Vay, his friends obtained for him after it few months the appointment of trwylnaldji or receiver of the petitions at Abdeen Palace. Once again in the stirrups, Mah. moud did not lose his time, and aware of the value of powerful connections, and the influence women have iy pushing husbands to the front, he was lucky enough to obtain the hand of one of Mansour Pasha's sisters, thus becoming brother-in law to Ismail's favorite daughter, H.H. the Princess Tewhida.

Moreover, a marriage into the rich and powerful Yegen family secured him the patronage of such men as Haidar, Barud, Kalil Pasha Yegen, Ali Pasha Cherif, and others. Sent twice to Candia with dispatches, this feat gainend him the rank of colonel, and during the last Russo Turkish war he commanded a regiment of cavalry under Prince Hanan, who is said to have had a poor idea of the gallant colonel's . military capacity.

On his return to Cairo it happened that an unscrupulous instrument was wanted for the part of Prefect of Police, and Mahmoud Sami volunteering, his services were accepted. In his new position be found opportunities for making friends with those he had been appointed to watch ; in fact it is stated that he knew all about the contemplated military movement of Pruary 1st, 1879. At any rate de managed to keep Ismail, as well as the Wilson ministry, pletely in the dark; yet so well did he' shule his cards, that he was soon after made a Missister; in fact, Cherif had to accept him as Minister of Wakfs and of Public Instruction.

In this capacity he countersigned, in August 1979, with his colleagues, what is commonly alleil Cherif's Constitution," and which forins, fts we hires, the basis of the present Organic 12. With the other ministers, he pledged uno u stand or to fall by the reform project of his chief, but Mahmoud Sami deserted in party as soon as the non-acceptance of Cherif proposals obliged the cabinet to resigi. Su turning his back on notables and stitution he went over to Riaz, who gave him the portfolio of the Wakfs, which he exchanged on February 1st, 1881, for that of Minister of War. The creat opportunity of his life now arrived. When Arabi formed the Camarella amongst the native Egyptian othcers, which maile the "three colonels" the chiefs of the native military organisation, the most important recruit outside the ranks of the army whose services were enlisted was Mahmoud Pasha Sami, the Minister of War. He was an Egyptian of Turkish descent, who saw an opportunity of advancing hiş own fortunes by associating himself with the conspiracy, and who, after the wont of Turks in Egypt, soon made himself the master of his fellow-conspirators. He soon di played his consummate treachery to the Khedive, for it was by his advice that the fellaheen officers issued a protest against the reduction of the 1: ;; and insisted on the post of Minister of Wer being entrusted to a native Egyptian. cabinet council was held, at which Mahmoud Sumi was present, and at which it was decider to summon the colonels to a meeting at the kasr el Nil barracks, on the plea of discussing their protest, and to arrest them if they persisted in their demands. Mahmoud Sami at once communicated the intentions of the Ministry to his confederates, and it was arranged that the regiments under their command should march on Kasr el Nil at the time appointed for the meeting and rescue their commanding offcers if any attempt was made to effect their arrest. The Khedive was betrayed, a mutiny followed, and as he had 10 troops on whom he could rely, he had to yield to the demand of the mutineers. Mahmoud Sami, as Minister of War, did everything in his power to secure the support of the army. The Khedive grew alarmned at the way his personal authority was being undermined and he suddenly replaced Mahmoud Sami at the War Office by his own brother-in-law, Daoud Pasha, a Circassian, Another meeting followed and Arabi only consented to withdraw his troops if the Ministry were dismissed. Cherif Pasha, much against his will, consented to accept the presidency of this new administration, in which Mahmoud Sami resumed his old position of Minister of War. In vain did Cherif Pasha protest, in vain did he point out that Mahmoud Sami had deserted the national and liberal cause, in vain did he declare that no confidence could be placed in a man who was one day for, and the next against, constitutional institutions. It was all useless, for Mahmon had bewitched his military patrons, and his appointment was made a conditio sin qui non. From the first he betrayed his chief and lis colleagues in the Ministry, and secretly encour: aging the intrigues of his subordinates, he made the War Office the centre of a conspiracy of which he and Arabi were the promoters, and which had for its sole object the overthrow of Cherif Pasha. How the Prime Minister tell, and Mahmoud Sami stepped into his place, how he gained the support of Mr. Wilfrid Blunt, and how, with Arabi as his Minister of War, the administration of Egypt passed abso lutely and entirely out of the hands of the Khedive, are known to everyone who takes any interest in the history of modern Egypt, for the events which followed led to the 'bombardment of Alexandria and the British Occupation of Egypt.

Four years ago El Baroudi was pardoned by the Khedive and on his return to Egypt from Ceylon was received by his Highness at Koubbeh. The Khedive restored to him all his civil rights, authorising him to buy and sell land and to administer his property. Sami Pasha had for several years been afflicted with blindness. In the latter years of his life fortune favored him. Three years ago he bought 6 teddans of land at Manial for the sum of L.E. 4,000 ; to-day they are worth over L,E.30.000. He recently let his house at Darb elGamamiz, where the Mehkemeh Sharieh is installed, to the Government, and repaired his residence at Bab-el-Khalk, which is one of the finest in Cairo.

Sami Pasha was a well-known Arabic poet and a man of letters of no mean order. During the last two years he had published four bulky volumes giving extracts from eight of the greatest Arabic poets of inodern times. His funeral on Tuesday was of an imposing character, being attended by a large gathering of natives.

div.head: ESCAPE IN SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: Twelve men of that regiment of dare devils, the Foreign Legion, have successfully deserted in a peculiarly audacious way. The Messageries Maritimes steamer Cao Bany was passing the Suez Canal, outward bound, with troops for French Indo-China. Apparently a number of foreign legionaries on board had had enough of military service, for which, of course, all the men of the corps have volunteered, as none are of French nationality, or else they had changed their minds regarding the attractions of the Far East. Anyhow, one afternoon seven of them jumped overboard. One was 'canght by the steamer's screws and went under. The six others, escaping sharks, swain safely ashore, where they proceeded to wave their caps derisively at the boat. Two hours later 'six more foreign legionaries followed suit, two - of them being recaptured and put in irons, while the four others successfully joined the six already on land. The next morning two more men of the corps jumped overboard, and - escaped both pursuers and sharks. It is not known what has become of the twelve deserters who landed and were left behind.

div.head: EGYPT AND CRETE.
div.p: In the Annual of the British School at Athens, Mr. Evans calls attention to the evidence of close relations between Crete and Egypt-clumps of crocuses used in decorations as adaptation of clumps of lotus flower, and a painted jar with papyrus reliefs; but he does not touch the important question of the relation between the earlier and the later civilization of Crete. Evidently he is waiting for new evidence,

Sir Percy Girouard, K.C.M.G., who is so well known in Wypt in connection with rail. way work, has just been promoted Lieutenant Colonel from Captain and Brevet-Major in the Royal Engineers, for "listinguished services of an exceptional nature other than in the field." This is Sir Percy's reward for his brilliant rail. way work during and after the South African campaign.

Major and Brevet-Colonel G. G. Cunningham, C.B., D.SI). Royal Scots, second in command of the 21 Batalion at Kamptee, has been promoted lieutenant-colonel of the 1st Battalion at Woking. Colonel Cunningham has had a varied campaigning career, having seen active service in Egypt against Arabi's army, where he was twice wounded, and with the Egyptian Army he gained repute on the Nile with Earle's force and the operations of the Sudan Frontier force, and in West Africa he parti: cipated in no fewer than five expeditions.

Captain H. W. Pearson, Royal Engineers, who for some time has been acting as Staff Captain in the Department of the Director of Military Operations, goes back to Egypt for service wil. th, Khedive's army. He went through the Tirah expedition 1897-98 and the Boxer (ainpaign 1901-02.
Owing to the increase of the Military Mounted Police necessitated by the stationing of an entire squadron in Egypt, the establishinent of that force has been considerably augmented.

The S.S. Plassy left Southampton on the 6th inst. for Bombay with some 800 troops--chietis artillerymen--and details on board for vari us batteries and companies in India. The Plass, is due to reach Bombay about the 30th inst. Leaving Bibig on the 6th prox, with timeexpired men she is timed to arrive at Southampton on the 28th prox.

The net result of all changes which are being eflected in the navy at home and abroad will be that in the course of a few weeks' time Great Britain will have concentrated in home waters and in the Atlantic a huge naval "striking force" of an irresistible power capable of smashing any combination against it. In short, it is a complete triumph for the "blue water school" whose first tenet is not detence but the meeting of an enemy on its own shores, and naval supremacy in the Atlantic, the great lighway of European nations.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandria
div.p: SERVICES SANITAIRES
AVIS

Il est rappelé aux vendeurs des substances vénéneuses déjà autorisés en vertu de l'arrêté du 13 Juin 1891 qu'il est nécessaire d'obtenir de nouvelles autorisations dans le délai de 90 jours à partir de la publication du Décret du 15 Septembre qui eut lieu dans le Journal Officiel français le 19 Septembre 1904 et dans le Journal Officiel arabe le 21 du même mois. Les autorisations qu'ils détiennent actuelle- ment seront done nulles après le 21 Décembre 1904.

L'examen qu'auront à subir les vendeurs de substances venéneuses, conformément à l'art. 12, avant d'obtenir les autorisations nécessai- res, aura lieu pour la ville d'Alexandrie le 1er Lundi de chaque mois à l'Hôpital du Gouvernement.
Exceptionnellement les premiers examens auront lieu dans le dit établissement les 14 et 19 Décembre 1904 à 9 h. a.m.
Les personnes sollicitant l'autorisation de faire le commerce des substances vénéneuses devront justifier des connaissances suivantes.
1°Connaitre toutes les dispositions du Règle- ment sur la vente des substances vénéneuses.
2° Savoir lire et écrire sous dictée les noms de toutes les substances mentionnées dans le Tableau II annexé au Règlement.
3° Connaitre parfaitement les poids et me- sures du système métrique.

4° Savoir distinguer 15 articles au moins des Ne substances suivantes: Cobalte, (arsen-métalli- que), acide arsénieux, Realgar (sulfure rouge d'arsenic), Auripigment (sulfure jaune d'arse- nic), Acide hydrocyanique, Cyanure de potasse, Bichlorure de mercure, Bisulfate de mercure, Oxide mercurique jaune, Oxide mercurique C rouge, Acétate de plomb, Sulfate de zinc, Chlo- rure de zinc, Tartre stibié, Acétate de cuivre, Phosphore, Chloroforme, Acide picrique, Acide oxalique.
5° Expliquer l'usage des substances mention- nées dans le Tableau II et dire comment elles doivent être renfermées et étiquettées.
6° Pouvoir tenir régulièrement les registres pour la vente des substances vénéneuses.

Les personnes qui subiront avec succès l'exa inen precité pourront obtenir l'autorisation né cessaire pour la vente des substances véné- neuses. Toutefois l'autorisation ne sera délivrée anx interessés qu'après que l'autorité sanitaire se sera assurée que le local destiné à la vente est bien acre et non humide, qu'il est propre et que le nom de la personne autorisée est lisiblement écrit sur le devant du local.

Les personnes désirant obtenir l'autorisation de vendre une ou diverses substances vénéneuses devront être tenues à distinguer seulement les 0 articles pour lesquels l'autorisation est sollicitée, 20 et dans le cas où l'autorisation est accordée, 20 il sera nettement stipulé sur la permission que le porteur est autorisé à vendre seulement ces substances et aucunes autres.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: The Editor of the Egyptian Gazette will be pleased to receive communication dealing with matters of local interest, for publication. Notes of events occuring in the Provinces are especially welcome.
All communications should be sent to "THE EDITOR," and be accompanied by the Writer's Name and Address, not necessarily for in sertion, but as a guarantee of good faith.
The Editor will not undertake to return any contribution unaccompanied by a stamp and return address.
